segments.speaker: Annie Gavica
segments.words: And so, they needed a lot of people to work here and come here. segments.speaker: Annie Gavica
segments.words: And then as history progresses, we get more closer to current day. And so we had examples of those people doctors, lawyers, politicians, Pete Santa Rosa and Benny Sirsa, secretaries of state for the state of Idaho, were some of the longest running secretaries of state.

segments.speaker: Annie Gavica
segments.words: And so with that, the connection in and of itself that made with Idaho and the Basque community in the Basque Country is a very strong connection. And so there's often exchanges, political exchanges between Idaho, even sometimes the city of Boise, because Mayor Beta was prior to mayor McLean was of Basque ancestry as well. segments.speaker: Annie Gavica
segments.words: So there's a strong political bonds, there's a strong kind of work ethic. And, and bond. And then since 1900s so more than 100 years, just the presence I think has added to it. segments.words: And then what is the demographic of Basque people that currently have a job within, like the sheep ranching industry? You know, that kind of agricultural field, if you know that.

segments.words: They few of them would, purchase their own sheep, maybe, and eventually have their own sheep ranches. They were working for sheep ranchers. There's a couple examples. segments.speaker: Annie Gavica
segments.words: So there's a good push. There's definitely some that are. They are Basque because they have a Basque last name and that's all they know. segments.speaker: Annie Gavica

segments.words: And then circling back to the origin of the Basque language, you know, and how it's that isolated language with no, you know, definitive connection. Is there any, you know, current origin, at least theory that's out there right now, or is it still just kind of we really don't know.

metadata.description: This presentation explores the unique history of the Basques from the late 19th century to today, their global immigration, and their impact on communities, especially in Idaho. Attendees will learn about Spain and France before mass Basque emigration, the region’s transformation into a major tourist destination, and the hardships Basques faced during the immigration process. The talk will highlight their perseverance in establishing communities across the western U.S. and their lasting impact on local culture. The Basque Museum & Cultural Center preserves and shares these stories to connect people of all backgrounds and celebrate the dignity of the human experience. Bio: Annie, a fourth-generation Basque-American, was born and raised on a cattle ranch in Paradise Valley, Nevada. She attended a small three-room grade school before continuing her education in Winnemucca. Active in student leadership and athletics, she carried that passion to Boise State University, earning a degree in Spanish with minors in Basque Studies and Business. She joined the Oinkari Basque Dancers, serving as a board member, dance director, and liaison for a decade. Her deep connections with Boise’s Basque community led to study, travel, and work opportunities in the Basque Block. Since college, Annie has worked in education and became the Education Program Specialist at the Basque Museum & Cultural Center in 2013. In 2016, she was appointed Executive Director, continuing the mission of preserving, promoting, and perpetuating Basque history and culture for future generations.
